serialKillers.name: Luis Alfredo Garavito Cubillos
serialKillers.bio: Luis Alfredo Garavito, known as 'La Bestia', was a Colombian serial killer and rapist. He was convicted of murdering at least 138 boys between 1992 and 1999. Garavito is considered one of the most notorious serial killers in history, operating primarily in Colombia, with possible activity in other Latin American countries.

trialDetails.sentence: 1,853 years in prison (commuted to 22 years due to Colombian law)

quotes: I did it, yes. But it was the Devil who possessed me.
evidence: Belongings of victims found in his possession

serialKillers.name: Pedro Alonso López
serialKillers.bio: Pedro Alonso López, known as the 'Monster of the Andes', is a Colombian serial killer who was convicted of murdering at least 110 girls across Colombia, Peru, and Ecuador during the 1970s. He is suspected of killing over 300 victims, making him one of the most prolific serial killers in history.

trialDetails.sentence: Life imprisonment (released after 14 years due to Ecuadorian law)

serialKillers.name: Pedro Rodrigues Filho
serialKillers.bio: Pedro Rodrigues Filho, known as 'Pedrinho Matador' (Little Pedro the Killer), was a Brazilian vigilante serial killer. He claimed to have killed over 100 criminals, including drug dealers, rapists, and even inmates while he was incarcerated. His actions were driven by a sense of twisted justice, making him one of Brazil's most infamous figures.
quotes: I killed them because they deserved it.
I am a good person. I only kill bad people.
serialKillers.finalWords: I have no regrets for what I did.

serialKillers.name: Andrei Chikatilo
serialKillers.bio: Andrei Chikatilo was a Soviet serial killer, responsible for the murder of at least 52 people between 1978 and 1990. He is infamously known as the 'Butcher of Rostov' due to the gruesome nature of his crimes, which primarily targeted women and children. Chikatilo's horrific acts of violence were characterized by sexual assault, mutilation, and cannibalism. His eventual capture and trial in the early 1990s became one of the most notorious cases in Russian history, highlighting failures in the criminal justice system.
quotes: I killed for the pleasure.
It was a compulsion.

serialKillers.name: Gary Leon Ridgway
serialKillers.bio: Gary Leon Ridgway, known as the 'Green River Killer,' is an American serial killer who was convicted of killing 49 women in Washington state during the 1980s and 1990s. He targeted vulnerable women, including sex workers and runaways, often disposing of their bodies in the Green River. Ridgway is one of the most prolific serial killers in U.S. history.

serialKillers.name: Dean Corll
serialKillers.bio: Dean Corll, known as the 'Candy Man,' was an American serial killer who, between 1970 and 1973, abducted, tortured, and murdered at least 28 young boys in Houston, Texas. Corll's nickname came from his family's candy business, which he used to lure victims. He is often remembered for the horrific nature of his crimes and the involvement of his teenage accomplices.

serialKillers.name: John Wayne Gacy

serialKillers.name: Jeffrey Dahmer
serialKillers.bio: Jeffrey Dahmer, also known as the 'Milwaukee Cannibal,' was an American serial killer and sex offender who murdered and dismembered 17 young men and boys between 1978 and 1991. serialKillers.name: Alexander Pichushkin

Pichushkin was arrested in 2006 and later convicted of 48 murders.

serialKillers.name: Ahmad Suradji
serialKillers.bio: Ahmad Suradji, known as 'The Sorcerer,' was an Indonesian serial killer active from 1986 to 1997. He was convicted of murdering 42 women, whom he claimed he needed to sacrifice to enhance his mystical powers as a traditional sorcerer. Suradji lured his victims to his home in North Sumatra, where he would strangle them and then bury their bodies. serialKillers.name: Dennis Rader
serialKillers.bio: Dennis Rader, infamously known as the BTK Killer (Bind, Torture, Kill), is an American serial killer who committed a series of murders in Kansas from 1974 to 1991. He taunted police and media with letters detailing his crimes, evading capture for decades. Rader was arrested in 2005 after DNA evidence linked him to the murders. He was convicted of ten counts of first-degree murder and sentenced to ten consecutive life sentences without the possibility of parole. His case raised concerns about the psychological motives of serial killers and their manipulation of law enforcement.

serialKillers.name: Ivan Milat
serialKillers.bio: Ivan Milat was an Australian serial killer convicted of the murders of seven backpackers in the 1990s. His gruesome crimes, which included abduction, torture, and murder, took place in the Belanglo State Forest in New South Wales. Milat evaded capture for years until a task force was established, leading to his arrest in 1994. He was found guilty of multiple murders and received a life sentence without parole. Milat's case shocked Australia and raised concerns about the safety of travelers in remote areas.

serialKillers.name: Carl Panzram
serialKillers.bio: Carl Panzram was an American serial killer, rapist, arsonist, and burglar. Born in 1891, Panzram claimed to have killed at least 21 people and committed numerous acts of violence and robbery throughout his life. He had a tumultuous childhood marked by abuse, leading to a life of crime. Panzram was eventually captured and sentenced to death for his crimes. He is often remembered for his bold and defiant personality, which he displayed even during his incarceration, and for his philosophical writings on violence and revenge. He was executed in 1930.

serialKillers.name: Rodney Alcala
serialKillers.bio: Rodney Alcala was an American serial killer and rapist who gained notoriety as 'The Dating Game Killer' after appearing as a contestant on the television show 'The Dating Game' in 1978. He was convicted of the murders of several young women and girls during the 1970s, although authorities believe he may have committed many more. Alcala's charming demeanor and good looks helped him lure his victims, leading to a string of brutal killings. He was apprehended multiple times but managed to evade long-term incarceration until his final arrest in 2010. Alcala was sentenced to death and died in 2021 while on death row.
quotes: I can’t help myself. I have to do it.
There are no real victims, only people who get in the way.

serialKillers.name: Aileen Wuornos
serialKillers.bio: Aileen Wuornos was an American serial killer who murdered seven men in Florida between 1989 and 1990. Born into a troubled family and experiencing a difficult childhood, Wuornos turned to prostitution to survive. She claimed that her victims had assaulted her while she was working, leading her to kill in self-defense. Wuornos was captured in 1991 and eventually convicted of her crimes. Her life and murders became the subject of significant media attention, and she was executed by lethal injection in 2002. Wuornos's story has raised discussions about mental health, poverty, and the treatment of women in society.
quotes: I’m not a monster.
I killed for love.
serialKillers.finalWords: I’d just like to say I’m sorry for what I’ve done.

serialKillers.name: Edmund Kemper
serialKillers.bio: Edmund Kemper is an American serial killer and necrophile who murdered ten people, including his grandparents, mother, and six young women, in California during the 1960s and 1970s. Known for his towering stature and intelligence, Kemper was often referred to as 'The Co-ed Killer' due to his pattern of targeting young female students. After his arrest in 1973, he confessed to his crimes in detail, providing insights into his disturbed psyche. Kemper was found to be sane and was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole, where he remains to this day. His life and crimes have been the subject of numerous documentaries and books.
quotes: I had a real need to kill, to kill more and more.
I wanted to see how it felt to kill someone.

serialKillers.name: Joseph James DeAngelo
serialKillers.bio: Joseph James DeAngelo is an American serial killer, rapist, and former police officer who was active during the 1970s and 1980s. He is infamously known as the 'Golden State Killer' for his series of crimes, which included at least 13 murders, over 50 rapes, and more than 120 burglaries across California. His criminal activities created widespread fear and panic, and he evaded capture for decades. In 2018, advances in DNA technology led to his arrest. DeAngelo was charged with multiple counts of murder and other crimes, and he later pleaded guilty in 2020 to avoid a trial. He was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Hansen would often hunt his victims in the wilderness, using his skills as an experienced hunter. He was captured in 1983 after a victim escaped and reported him to the police. Hansen pleaded guilty to multiple charges and was sentenced to 461 years in prison, where he died in 2014.

serialKillers.name: Leonard Lake and Charles Ng
serialKillers.bio: Leonard Lake and Charles Ng were American serial killers who committed a series of murders in California during the early 1980s. Lake's horrific plan was to create a 'slave colony' for women, while Ng assisted in the abductions and killings. The duo was responsible for the deaths of at least 11 victims, but the true number may be much higher. Leonard Lake died by suicide in jail in 1985, while Ng was captured and later convicted of multiple counts of murder.

serialKillers.name: Peter Sutcliffe
serialKillers.bio: Peter Sutcliffe, known as 'The Yorkshire Ripper', was a British serial killer who terrorized northern England from 1975 to 1980. He was responsible for the murders of 13 women and attempted to kill seven others, primarily targeting sex workers in Leeds and Bradford. Sutcliffe's crimes were characterized by their brutality, and he evaded capture for several years, largely due to police miscommunication. He was arrested in 1980 and was sentenced to 20 concurrent life sentences in 1981. He died in prison in 2020.

serialKillers.name: Kenneth Bianchi and Angelo Buono
serialKillers.bio: Kenneth Bianchi and Angelo Buono were American serial killers who, together, committed a series of murders in Los Angeles between 1977 and 1978. They are known for the brutal killings of at least 10 young women, whom they would abduct, sexually assault, and strangle. Their modus operandi involved luring victims to their vehicle, often by impersonating police officers. The case gained significant media attention and highlighted issues surrounding police and community safety in the area. Bianchi was ultimately captured after attempting to feign multiple personality disorder, while Buono was arrested shortly thereafter. Both were convicted and sentenced to life in prison.
